newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian Kras says has new potential investor.
newsitem.headline: Croatian Kras says has new potential investor.

text.p: Leading Croatian confectioner Kras said on Thursday it had a new potential investor in addition to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD).
"Talks with the EBRD are still going on, but there are other interesting propositions being discussed with another party," finance director Tomislav Jovic told Reuters.
He declined to reveal the identity of the new suitor.
He did not say whether it was a strategic investor from the same branch or a financial institution, interested in backing up the company's development plans with a loan.
The two sides agreed to treat negotiations confidentially until a final deal was reached, Jovic said, but added: "This could be very soon."
The EBRD was widely believed to be interested in granting a credit to the chocolate-maker and later converting it into an equity stake, as it did with drugs firm Pliva a year ago.
But talks have dragged on for months, with neither party appearing willing to disclose any concrete details.

Recent rumours about the deal being abandoned have gnawed at the price of Kras shares on Zagreb's bourse where it trades in the section for semi-regulated companies. Its shares closed five kuna lower at 415 on Wednesday.
This compares to the 430-460 kuna range Kras traded at last month and a high of 550 kuna, recorded earlier in the year.

However Jovic said the company paid little attention to the market speculation and was interested in "securing a sound basis for its share growth". -- Kolumbina Bencevic, Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
